pros: Autonomy (but diminishing) Great supervisor Close to the mall if you're into that Relaxed dress code 35 hour work week Team is about 85% cohesive
cons: Department does not really know what she's doing Nothing is in writing, so people are guessing what is right and wrong Department yells at the people who work under her and expect to have a sustainable team Having a degree has no value unless you're faculty, then it still has little value Taking a lunch is frowned upon as well as leaving at 5:00, which is the time you're scheduled to work There is no overtime, so anything worked past 5:00 is volunteered Not much learning experience or growth Turnover is EXTREMELY high with 8 people leaving in a 9-month timeframe and a 16-person team Work will be piled on you, and you're expected to complete it by staying late Some people are working until 8 and 9 o'clock at night and not being compensated (it is supposedly included in the small salary you get) Direct quote from department: "Administrators shouldn't be taking an hour for lunch." (though our paperwork says we get an hour lunch and leave at 5 o'clock)

pros: Benefits are good but, expensive
cons: remote work is not really an option

job_title: Resident Safety Representative in Uniondale, NY
pros: You are allowed to do home work while on the job.
cons: Must work 16 hours every week at minimum.

pros: Hofstra has been innovating and reinventing itself for more than a decade. It's also close now to becoming a Level 2 Research University. There is an infectious sense of congeniality among colleagues from across the campus seeking to raise the university's profile, and most importantly the academic programs for our students.
cons: Too little parking on the academic side of campus.

pros: Beautiful campus, good benefits, free parking

review_title: Hostile Work Environment- Resident Safety Program
pros: My co-workers were also students attending Hofstra and they were great people to know and work with.
cons:
*I have been told she no longer works at Hofstra however*:
The manager created a hostile work environment in the office. She screamed, micro-managed, and talked badly about employees behind their backs to other employees. She was narcissistic, abusive, and sexually harassed her subordinates. Her behavior was illegal and she was reported by multiple people. The laws that exist are put in place to protect us from people like her. However, unfortunately, the university did not fire her, she left on her own terms. I am not sure who the current manager is but this is who they hired before so I'm not sure how good they are at picking quality people.

Even though this was the highest position available in the program we still didn't make minimum wage. The university is allowed to pay the federal minimum wage so after being promoted twice I still only made $13.75 an hour.

Always on call and bringing work home or staying late. The job did not need to be like this but the constant stress from management demanded it. Many tasks and procedures were regularly overcomplicated by the manager.

job_title: Hofstra University Student Assistant in Hempstead, NY
pros: Great campus and growth of university.
cons: To many politics on campus

pros: I have nothing but positive things to say about this place. Hofstra is a wonderful, enriching and nurturing environment, They offer good benefits, supportive supervisors, inspiring staff and ever evolving facilities and technology. I was able to obtain my masters degree here for reduced cost even as a part timer. This is a fantastic, proven organization with strong academic programs and a commitment to growth and excellence. The campus exists in a park like setting with gorgeous architecture and meticulously maintained grounds. The university has been a generous, supportive benefactor to my department and has curated incredible opportunities for LHSOC students with well planned capital investments and organizational support.
cons: None really. I have nothing but the best things to say about my team and department. There is often professional and thoughtful communication among my supervisors and colleagues, which I see as a primary driver of success and productivity.

pros: Teaching. The University has a good on-boarding system and support at the begging of a professorship. After that, you are on your own as you navigate through departmental politics and all of the risks of tenure. There are some amazing and motivated students, and there are many who are in class to check off their to-do lists on the way to the careers their parents have designated. There is an intellectual atmosphere and a collegial feel. Make it a point to have a sit-down the president on one of the open-ffice days.
cons: The Hempstead area is one of the poorest areas on Long Island, yet housing prices do not reflect that. It's an hour from New York City by train and getting guest speakers to venture on the campus is challenging. It's tier 3 and trying hard.

review_title: Has been a decent experience. However, there are definite changes that the school should look into.
pros:
Great benefits- especially vacation days
Nice office space 
Flexible schedule
cons:
Oftentimes institution has a reactive instead of proactive approach to things

Feel like the institution is run like a business instead of an institution of learning 
 
Culture is very interesting- people trying to one up each other all the time and a lot of gossiping

Pay and raises could definitely improve- very low

review_title: Great environment to work and develop in!
pros:
Opportunity to participate in a variety of different tasks and projects. Strongly believe in allowing all staff members to voice ideas and gives the ideas opportunity to develop. The open positions are posted internally first for a lot of opportunities to move around and to move up. 

Provide tuition remission both in Undergrad and Grad and for children/spouse undergrad.
Beautiful place to work and feel comfortable coming to work each day.
cons:
Slow to change and not efficient in communicating the change. Union representatives are not supportive of the union employees and really only communicate at the end of the collective bargaining process.

Campus food was expensive which causes us to get off of campus and lose parking (though summer parking was great)

pros: I work with a great team, particularly my smaller team within the larger one.  My colleagues are a pleasure to work with on a day to day basis.  And it is an interesting job because no two appointments are the same.
cons: To work in higher education a master's degree is required, but the salary is paltry at best.  Colleagues in elementary education make money for years of service and education degrees, but that is not accounted for in higher education.  Yearly raises are about 2% and it is a low starting salary.

pros: Hofstra University's student aides are well treated and the job allows students to complete work during downtime. This makes it ideal for students with busy schedules who need cash.
cons: The hours are limited and Hofstra is allowed to pay less than the state minimum wage, which makes it difficult to make enough money to actually live on Long Island. Hofstra's pay schedule is spread out in a way that really makes it difficult to plan. Low pay and long periods between payments can make life hard.

review_title: Exceptional work environment, brilliant educational opportunities
job_title: Hofstra University Student Assistant in Hempstead, NY
pros: Hofstra is a melting pot for students, administrators, and faculty from all different walks of life. With 140 different major programs for students to choose from, employees interact with a plethora of different experiences on a daily basis. This free exchange of knowledge and ideas make the University an exceptional environment to foster creative thinking and innovation for all individuals.
cons:
Low compensation rate for Graduate Assistants (highest annual stipend amounts to $2,000) 
Student employees paid federal minimum wage, low chance for increasing that salary.

review_title: Great Environment to get in to Student Affairs
pros: Meet some of the best people who have the same amount of drive and motivation you  aspire to work with. Additionally, they teach you many techniques to inspire success.
cons: Low pay and sometimes a lazy work environment. The idea of the Hofstra Shuffle is very real and can be the most tiresome and annoying thing when working with other departments.

review_title: A place for learning not for working
pros: One of the upsides to working at Hofstra is the ability to take classes and free tuition.  You do get an hour lunch and the campus is beautiful. Also the other people that you work with are for the most part pleasant. You can form some friendships and people are in their roles for long periods of time.
cons: Hofstra is an okay place however, its location is very depressing. Hempstead is dangerous and students are rude. In fact almost everyone in the university is rude. The professors are very competent and have a passion for doing what they do however everyone else is miserable.

review_title: GOOD FOR STUDENT EMPLOYMENT ON COMPUS
job_title: Resident Safety Representative in Hempstead, NY
pros: The job is resident safety presentative, which is a easy job. The compensation is minimal wages that is $7.5 per hours. The working time is flexible and you can choose what time you want if the time is available. The supervisors are nice and willing to help if you have some difficulties.
cons: May have to work in the midnight and early in the morning. And some students are rude and may not respect you making the work hard sometimes. The salary is a little bit low and some hardwares need to be updated and fixed.

review_title: I have loved every minute of working for the Hofstra Math department
pros:
If you like teaching, Hofstra is great.
Colleagues are easy to get a long with.
Everyone is helpful and will get you what you need if you ask.
cons: Unfortunately, currently shrinking, so the number of classes available to teach is going to decrease. Some of the more senior staff is retiring in the next few years and it is a shame to see them go.

pros: The job has very flexible hours, and taking days off at short notice is okay. Good time off policies allowing for flexilibtiy and enough time to enjoy the vacation. Free college courses is a huge perk for all full-time employees.
cons:
Huge bureaucracy
Slow to change
Not great pay for the amount of work some people do.
There's a definite old-boy's club, some of which are women, that refuse to acknowledge that some of their ideas are outdated.

pros: There are no real pros for being an administrator. You work in an office, similar to every other 9-5 job and you will likely hate all of your coworkers.
cons: Office politics rule all, Hofstra is getting rid of the union, supposedly is doing fine finances wise but keeps laying off tons of people. Wages are constantly frozen also.

review_title: Hofstra University Zarb School of Business Traditional and Distance Learning Leadership
job_title: Adjunct Assistant Professor in Hempstead, NY
pros: Leading in applied strategy, innovation and technology learning. In particular, Zarb Schools leading educational program coverage through distance learning courses, its course content and DL faculty, faculty coverage on DL courses
cons: Areas to improve include marketing and promoting business school innovations in the media to attract, retain and graduate larger classes of business school students nationally and globally

review_title: working athletic events and other University events
pros: Good pay, great for on-campus living due to short travel, great managers and senior level management, good work and life balance
cons: were unable to allow you to work more than 20 hours per week when one could accomplish many more hours than that

pros: Generally supportive office working environment that appreciates the successes of employees. Up-to-date technology, comfortable working environment, and good intra- and inter-office rapport.
cons: Coworkers will occasionally 'tattle' on other employees instead of addressing a problem or complaint directly. Lots of gossip and in-group versus out-group dynamic affect employee interaction. Lack of parking.

job_title: Resident Assistant in Hofstra Univ, NY
pros: Free housing, good relationships with staff
cons: Lack of respect, large amount of work, low pay

job_title: Executive Secretary/Faculty Assistant in Hempstead, NY
pros: The have a good benefits, it is a great place to work, the people are nice and friendly. The professor are friendly and also the workers.
cons: The downsides of the Unversity is that they need more parking space. They need more hours instead of thirty-five hours need to work forty hours.

pros: You get free lunch by being an employee. It can be a great place to work but there is something different to work on.
cons: Your schedule will always be different you can never count on a steady routine. Also you can never move up to a better position just more work same pay.

review_title: I believe that Hofstra University is a fair company.
pros: The compensation is competitive with similar companies. The university is clean, up-to-date, and extraordinarily beautiful. The faculty is agreeable and fun to work with.
cons: Supervisors do not always give subordinates the respect they deserve. Also, the university is located in Hempstead (which is not the nicest city).

pros: The staff extras, secretaries, grad students, interns were great. The Chair was oblivious to the other profs. But it did help with the college costs
cons: This is a very liberal school. Any ideas outside of those that are politically correct are treated as hateful. There is no such thing as a fair assessment. if you are a Christian.

pros: The staff is very diverse in terms of educational background and real life experience which allows for synergistic collaboration between and within various parts of the school
cons: Average salary, there is not always a good work life balance as some of the working hours are not the best

pros: A highly organized, detail-oriented administrative assistant with experience providing thorough and skillful administrative and business support to the directors, the legal and finance departments.
cons: Need to learn how to delegate more

review_title: It is a great place to work while going to school, everyone is excepting and willing to tech you new things.
job_title: Learning Support Specialist in Hempstead, NY
pros: Everyone is nice, fun, and good to work with. They are usually flexible with hours and understand your schedule.
cons: Balancing schoolwork and working can be hard sometimes, but they try to help with that.

job_title: Hofstra University Student Assistant in Hempstead, NY
pros: Potentially a good source of student employment...if you know where to find it. Jobs usually pay fairly well for entry-level positions (~$9/hour). There are many different sources of employment on campus to choose from.
cons: Many sources of employment on campus do not allow you to choose your own hours. Some jobs force you to work during odd hours of the night (i.e. 4 A.M.).

review_title: Not bad work, but the pay is awful
job_title: Resident Safety Representative in Hofstra Univ, NY
pros: Do homework at work; free access to cable TV; lots of time to yourself; many empty shifts
cons: Pay is federal minimum wage ($7.25); scheduling a replacement can be a nightmare; high turnover rate; can be boring

review_title: Overall good place to work, but needs major changes to keep employees happy and to get them to stay long term.
pros: Benefits, work-life balance for non-traveling positions, co-workers.
cons: Working weekends, inconsistent management, out-of-touch President and other VPs.

pros: Very friendly environment with amicable staff. Responsibilities are a bit much but he experience you get out of it is phenomenal. Perfect leadership experience!
cons: Very big time commitment. Energy levels must also be up constantly. You must be willing to work hard and put in 110%

pros: Flexible in your class schedule.
cons: You're only going to make about 3000 for the school year. After you meet your cap you have to find another job or wait til the next semester to work. And if you don't use all of your hours they go away, there is no rolling over of the funds.

job_title: Operations Manager in New York, NY
pros: The campus is vibrant in the spring and summer with countless cross departmental integrations. There is good room for growth personally and institutionally.
cons:
Hofstra is on a path for greatness, but needs to increase its attention to tech and its growing important in today's world. 
Like every university, bureaucracy exists here with no sign of weakening.

review_title: Started as a student, now teaching
pros: Great environment, people at Hofstra Unversity are interesting to work with, you can get your degree while working, also concerts, programs, plays, physical fitness facility, pool as work perks.
cons: The world is not perfect, but most staff are interested in getting along with each other, helping other employees, helping students, etc.

pros: Great benefits, vacation time, 401k, holidays. The people who work there are great!
cons: It's very difficult to move departments or positions. You often get locked into a job and expect to be in that position for a long time.

job_title: Rsr Safety in Hofstra Univ, NY
pros: The best thing about working at Hofstra is flexible schedules and the proximity to clases.
cons: The worse thing is the pay. Since it is considered student work, the pay is below minimum wage.

pros:

- Freedom to make what I want of this job
- Creative atmosphere

cons:

Opportunity to learn more about technical support
Bosses are always understanding
cons: None that I can think of

cons: Hofstra deducts half an hour after you cross 5 hours for the day for lunch break

review_title: Hofstra is a Good Place to Work!
pros: Hofstra is a beautiful college, and it has great professors who care about the students and offer many opportunities for growth.
cons: Hofstra needs more parking on campus, but parking spots can be found.

job_title: Resident Safety Shift Coordinator in West Haven, CT

cons: Have to do one overnight. A lot of work compared to RSR position. Probably could get more money working off-campus.

review_title: Great students and colleagues, but no benefits
job_title: Adjunct Assistant Professor in Brooklyn, NY
pros: The students are great, the campus is beautiful, and my colleagues are wonderful.
cons: There are no healthcare benefits or benefits of any kind for adjunct employees. The campus itself is safe, but the area around the campus is dangerous.

pros: Good to learn knowledge and experience in school. You can focus on the subjects and different areas of studying. you have lots of your own time to decide what to do.
cons: limited work time and salary. you won't live only depends this role.

review_title: For the most part, great people
pros: Worked with motivated group of people providing tutoring support.  There were never scheduling issues or a lack of people to help.
cons: Pay wasn't great, but it was part time.

review_title: Likes to Toot Its Own Horn a Lot but You'd Make More Money at a CUNY
job_title: Administrative Secretary in New York, NY
pros: Benefits (med/vision/dental, 403b, tuition remission)
cons: Expensive benefits that lessen more and more every year, bad management, refuses to listen to the union of support staff workers

pros: Adjunct faculty is unionized together with the regular faculty and this ensures some protections
cons: Little support for Humanities, always in a funding crisis and cutting programs/support; perpetual state of essentially a 'hiringfreeze';  little support for either digital research or classroom innovation
